Where an exit stairway, an escalator or a moving walkway serves as a required exit, it shall be separated from the remainder of the building in accordance with Sentence 3.4.4.1.(1) of the 1986 Building Code.
Doors in fire separations required in Sentence (1) shall be equipped with self-closing devices.
An existing fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min with closures having a fire-protection rating not less than 45 min is deemed to comply with Sentence (1).
Existing wired glass screens set in fixed steel frames are acceptable in fire separations required by this Article.
Exits through a lobby area shall comply with the requirements of Clauses 3.4.4.1.(7)(c) to (f) of the 1986 Building Code.

Despite Sentence (1), there may be more than one exit through a lobby area if there is at least one alternate exit not through the lobby or an occupied space that is capable of serving at least 50% of the occupant load and that leads directly to the outside.

Storage rooms, refuse storage rooms and laundry rooms that open directly into an exit stairway shall be sprinklered and separated from the exit stairway by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.
Other rooms that open directly into an exit stairway shall be separated from the exit stairway by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.
Despite Sentences (1) and (2), existing rooms opening directly into an exit stairway may be approved.
Openings adjacent to fire escapes shall comply with Sentence 3.4.7.13.(5) of the 1986 Building Code.
Existing openings are deemed to comply with Sentence (1) if each opening is sprinklered and the sprinkler system complies with Article 9.2.5.2.
Despite Sentences (1) and (2), existing openings may be approved.
Fire alarm and detection systems shall be installed in compliance with Subsection 3.2.4., excluding Article 3.2.4.7., of the 1986 Building Code.
Despite Sentence (1), existing fire alarm systems may be approved where the system reliability and performance will not increase the risk of life safety.
Access routes for fire fighting shall comply with Sentence 3.2.5.2.(1) of the 1986 Building Code.
Sentence (1) does not apply where the building is sprinklered.

Access routes that do not comply with Sentence (1) may be approved where available fire department equipment has access to the building or alternative provisions are made under Subsection 2.8.2. for such access.
Except as permitted in Sentence (3), sprinkler systems shall comply with Article 3.2.5.5. of the 1986 Building Code.

An existing sprinkler system is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where the average sprinkler discharge density over the design area is at least equal to the minimum density corresponding to the area for the hazard classification as defined in Table 9.2.5.A.
Where buildings with a ceiling height in excess of 9 m are required to be sprinklered, the design of the system shall be approved prior to installation.

The water supply requirements for an existing sprinkler system shall be based on the hazard classification, as determined in Table 9.2.5.A., and the minimum sprinkler discharge density, area of application and sprinkler spacing, as determined in NFPA 13, "Standard for the Installation of Sprinkler Systems", that corresponds to the hazard classification determined under Clause (a).
Clause (4)(b) does not apply to the water supply requirements for an existing sprinkler system in an arena or an exhibition hall.
The water supply requirements for an existing sprinkler system in an arena or an exhibition hall shall be based on the lesser area of 100% of the display area, or 280 m2.

This Section applies to boarding houses, lodging houses, rooming houses and private rest homes in which residents do not require care or treatment because of age, mental or physical limitations, where the building height does not exceed 3 storeys and the building area does not exceed 600 m2, lodging is provided for more than four persons in return for remuneration or the provision of services or both, and lodging rooms do not have both bathrooms and kitchen facilities for the exclusive use of individual occupants.

This Section applies to homes for special care within the meaning of the Homes for Special Care Act, where the building height does not exceed 3 storeys and the building area does not exceed 600 m2, sleeping accommodation is provided for more than three but not more than 10 residents, and residents do not require nursing care.
Revoked: O. Reg. 256/14, s. 327.

P/T Article Title: Exemption for MCSS residences and hotels
P/T Sentence Text: Subject to Sentence 9.3.1.1.(2), this Section does not apply to residential occupancies that are regulated under the Ministry of Community and Social Services Act.

P/T Article Title: Exemption for MCSS residences and hotels
P/T Sentence Text: This Section does not apply to a building or part of a building regulated under Section 9.9.
For the purposes of this Section,
Fire separations required by this Section to have a fire-resistance rating shall comply with Subsection 9.10.3. of the 1986 Building Code.
Floor assemblies shall be constructed as fire separations, and have a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min.
Existing floor assemblies with ceilings consisting of lath and plaster, gypsum board or noncombustible materials are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).

Where a basement does not contain a bedroom, recreation room, meeting room or hobby room, a fire separation having no fire-resistance rating between the basement and first storey is deemed to be in compliance with Clause 9.3.2.2.(1)(b).
Each guest room or suite of rooms shall have interior walls having a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min.
Existing wall assemblies consisting of membranes of lath and plaster or gypsum wallboard are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).

In a building where the building height is greater than 2 storeys or the building area is greater than 400 m2, a furnace room that is located on a floor area that contains a bedroom, recreation room, meeting room or hobby room shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.
Existing fire separations consisting of membranes of lath and plaster or gypsum board are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).

Where the required vertical fire separation in a furnace room is maintained and it is not practical in the circumstances to construct the ceiling as a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min, the furnace room area shall be sprinklered with a spacing that does not exceed 9.5 m2 per sprinkler head.
Closures in fire separations for a furnace room shall have a fire-protection rating not less than 45 min.
A hollow metal or kalamein door and frame are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (4).
Closures referred to in Sentences (4) and (5) shall be equipped with latches and self-closing devices.
Despite Sentence (1), fire dampers or fire-stop flaps are not required in ducts at penetrations of a fire separation.

Where a furnace room is separated to comply with the requirements of Article 9.3.2.5., sufficient combustion air shall be brought directly from the exterior for the proper combustion and safe operation of the appliance.
Each floor area shall be served by at least two exits.
Where sleeping accommodation is not provided for more than 10 persons, one exit from each of the first and second floor floor areas is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).
Where sleeping accommodation is not provided in the basement, one exit from the basement is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).
Exits required by Article 9.3.3.1. shall comply with the requirements of Articles 9.9.2.2. and 9.9.2.3. of the 1986 Building Code.
Despite Sentence 9.3.3.5.(1), not more than one required exit from the basement may lead through the first floor floor area.
Where sleeping accommodation is not provided for more than 10 persons, corridors that are contiguous to a stairway may form part of the stairway enclosure.
Only one stairway enclosure described in Sentence (3) may be used as an exit.
Where a fire escape of the type referred to in Article 9.3.3.4. is used as an exit, it is deemed to comply with the requirements of Articles 9.9.2.2. and 9.9.2.3. of the 1986 Building Code.

Despite Articles 9.3.3.1. and 9.3.3.2., alternative measures may be approved where, in the opinion of the Chief Fire Official, they will provide protection for life safety similar to the protection provided by compliance with Articles 9.3.3.1. and 9.3.3.2.
Each fire escape used as an exit shall be constructed in compliance with Article 3.4.7.13., excluding Sentences (4) and (5), of the 1986 Building Code.
Despite Sentence (1), existing fire escapes may be approved.
Access to fire escapes shall be from corridors.

Each exit other than a doorway opening directly onto a fire escape or to the outdoors at ground level shall be separated from the remainder of the building or from another exit by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min.
Existing exit stairways separated from the remainder of the building by walls consisting of lath and plaster or gypsum wallboard are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).
Despite Sentence (1), an existing separation of noncombustible material may be approved.
Floor separations shall be maintained at interior stairways that are not required exits.
The floor separation shall be maintained at an exit permitted in Sentence 9.3.3.2.(2).
Floor separations required in Article 9.3.3.6. shall be rated in accordance with Articles 9.3.2.2. and 9.3.3.5.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Closures in fire separations required under Article 9.3.3.5. and in floor separations required under Article 9.3.3.6. shall be constructed in accordance with Article 9.10.3.1. of the 1986 Building Code, have a fire-protection rating not less than 20 min, and if the closure is openable, be equipped with self-closing and latching devices.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Closures located along contiguous corridors permitted in Sentence 9.3.3.2.(3) shall comply with Sentence (1).

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: A 45 mm solid core wood, hollow metal or kalamein door, equipped with self-closing and latching devices, is deemed to comply with Sentences (1) and (2).

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Despite Sentences (1) and (2), frames for doors described in Sentence (3) may be of wood, hollow metal or kalamein construction.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Despite Sentences (1) and (2), fire dampers or fire-stop flaps are not required in ducts at penetrations of a fire separation.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Existing wired glass closures set in fixed steel frames in a fire separation are deemed to be in compliance with Article 9.3.3.8.
Exit signs shall be located along a means of egress so that directions of exit travel are apparent to the occupants.

Exit signs required by Sentence (1) shall have the word "EXIT" in block letters and such letters shall be internally or externally illuminated, coloured red on an opaque or contrasting field, and at least 115 mm high with a 19 mm stroke.
The flame-spread rating of interior finishes on walls and ceilings within a means of egress shall not exceed 200.
Corridors and stairways shall be lighted to the intensity of 50 lx measured at the floor level, or 5 watts/m2 of floor area.

Where sleeping accommodation is provided for more than 10 persons, emergency lighting shall be provided to corridors and stairways in accordance with Articles 9.9.11.4. and 9.9.11.5. of the 1986 Building Code.

A building to which this Section applies that does not have floor assemblies having a minimum 45 min fire-resistance rating and public corridors or corridors serving sleeping rooms not within a dwelling unit that are not fire-separated from the remainder of the building by a minimum 30 min fire-resistance rating shall have a fire alarm system that complies with Articles 9.10.17.5. and 9.10.17.11. of the 1986 Building Code, and shall have smoke alarms that comply with Sentence (2) and that are installed and interconnected so that the activation of any smoke alarm will sound a similar signal in each of the interconnected devices, or fire alarm system smoke detectors installed on the ceiling of each floor adjacent to each stairway, and on the ceiling in the basement adjacent to each stairway.

Smoke alarms referred to in Clause (1)(a) shall be installed on the ceiling in the corridor of each floor adjacent to each stairway and on the ceiling in the basement adjacent to each stairway, be on a separate circuit with no disconnect switch between the overcurrent device and the smoke alarms, and employ devices and an interconnected installation that are listed.

A fire alarm system complying with Articles 9.10.17.4., 9.10.17.5., 9.10.17.11. and Subsection 9.10.18. of the 1986 Building Code shall be installed where sleeping accommodation is provided for more than 10 persons, and the floor assemblies have a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min and public corridors or corridors serving sleeping rooms not within a dwelling unit are separated from the remainder of the building by fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min.

Where a fire alarm system is required and sleeping accommodation is not provided for more than 14 persons, an interconnected smoke alarm system in accordance with Clause 9.3.4.1.(1)(a) is deemed to be in compliance with Article 9.3.4.2.
Despite Articles 9.3.4.1. and 9.3.4.2., existing fire alarm systems may be approved where the system reliability and performance will not increase the risk of life safety.
Despite the provisions of Subsection 6.2.6., at least one 2A rated portable extinguisher shall be provided on each floor.
At least one 5B:C rated portable extinguisher shall be installed in each kitchen where shared cooking facilities exist.

This Section applies to homes for special care regulated under the Homes for Special Care Act in which sleeping accommodation is provided for more than 10 residents, long-term care homes regulated under the Long-Term Care Homes Act, 2007, private hospitals regulated under the Private Hospitals Act, or public hospitals regulated under the Public Hospitals Act.
Revoked: O. Reg. 256/14, s. 337.

For the purposes of this Section, “1986 Building Code” means Ontario Regulation 419/86, as it read on February 11, 1987;
“existing” means in existence on February 11, 1987.
Fire separations required under this Section to have a fire-resistance rating shall comply with Subsection 3.1.5. and Articles 3.1.6.1., 3.1.6.2. and 3.1.6.3. of the 1986 Building Code.

If a fire-resistance rating of 1 h or less is required, existing wall assemblies, floor assemblies and ceilings and their supporting assemblies are deemed to comply with Sentence (1) if they consist of lath and plaster or gypsum board.
Heavy timber construction that complies with Article 3.1.4.4. of the 1986 Building Code is deemed to have a 45 min fire-resistance rating.
Buildings with limited combustible components may be approved as noncombustible construction.
Floor assemblies shall be constructed as fire separations with fire-resistance ratings in accordance with this Subsection.

Buildings of combustible construction shall comply with the provisions of Sentence (2) where the building is 1 storey in building height and not greater than 1000 m2 in building area, or 2 storeys in building height and not greater than 500 m2 in building area.
Floor assemblies and walls, columns and arches supporting floor assemblies shall have a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.
Despite Sentence (2), where the building is sprinklered, a fire-resistance rating is not required for floor assemblies or for walls, columns and arches supporting floor assemblies.

Buildings of combustible construction shall comply with the provisions of Sentences (2) and (3) where the building is not more than 1 storey in building height and not greater than 2400 m2 in building area, not more than 2 storeys in building height and not greater than 1600 m2 in building area, or not more than 4 storeys in building height and not greater than 500 m2 in building area.
Floor assemblies and walls, columns and arches supporting floor assemblies shall have a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.
Despite Sentence 9.4.4.2.(2), smoke detectors shall be provided in bedrooms, corridors, lounges and sitting areas.
A building that is sprinklered is deemed to be in compliance with Sentences (2) and (3).

Buildings not described in Articles 9.4.2.2. and 9.4.2.3. shall have a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min for floor assemblies and walls, columns and arches supporting floor assemblies, and be sprinklered, where the building is of combustible construction.

If only the roof assembly of a building is of combustible construction, the building is deemed to comply with Clause (1)(b) if the top storey and attic space are sprinklered, or the ceiling membrane has a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min and the attic space is fire stopped in accordance with Article 3.1.9.3. of the 1986 Building Code.
Fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h shall be provided between occupancies regulated under this Section and other major occupancies.

Fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min are deemed to comply with Sentence (1) if the building is sprinklered and the sprinkler system complies with Article 9.4.5.2., or the part of the building containing the other major occupancy is equipped with heat detectors and connecting corridors are equipped with smoke detectors as part of the fire alarm system of the building.
Existing wall or floor assemblies consisting of masonry or membranes of lath and plaster or gypsum board are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).

P/T Article Title: Fire separations between bedrooms and corridors
P/T Sentence Text: Bedrooms or compartments containing related rooms shall be separated from adjacent rooms by fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.

P/T Article Title: Fire separations between bedrooms and corridors
P/T Sentence Text: Corridors serving bedrooms shall be separated from adjacent rooms, except sitting areas, lounges, nurses stations and washrooms, by fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.

P/T Article Title: Fire separations between bedrooms and corridors
P/T Sentence Text: Where the floor area is sprinklered, an existing fire separation is deemed to be in compliance with Sentences (1) and (2).

P/T Article Title: Fire separations between bedrooms and corridors
P/T Sentence Text: A fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min is deemed to comply with Sentences (1) and (2) if smoke detectors are installed in bedrooms, sitting areas, lounges and corridors serving bedrooms on the floor area, and heat detectors are installed in other rooms opening onto corridors serving bedrooms.
Floor areas containing rooms or areas used by the residents shall be separated into at least two zones by fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.

Each zone required in Sentence (1) shall contain at least one acceptable exit, and be able to accommodate, in addition to its own occupants, the occupants of the adjacent zone, based on the requirements of 0.5 m2 of clear floor space per person, 1.6 m2 per person in a wheelchair, and 2.4 m2 for each bedridden patient as the occupancy requires.

A fire separation is not required under Sentence (1) where the travel distance between exits does not exceed 9 m and the number of occupants on the floor area is not more than 10 persons, or the floor area is served by exterior exit doors leading directly to the outside.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Closures in fire separations shall comply with the requirements of Sentences 3.1.6.4.(2), 3.1.6.7.(1) and 3.1.6.8.(1) and Article 3.1.6.9. of the 1986 Building Code.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Openings in a fire separation that is required to have a 30 min fire-resistance rating shall be protected with closures that have a fire-protection rating not less than 20 min.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Where Sentences (1) and (2) require a 1.5 h fire-protection rating, existing hollow metal doors, with or without wired glass panels not exceeding 645 cm2, equipped with self-closing devices and existing hollow metal frames are deemed to be in compliance, a 45 min fire-protection rating, existing hollow metal or kalamein doors, with or without wired glass, equipped with self-closing devices and existing hollow metal frames are deemed to be in compliance, a 45 min fire-protection rating, existing wired glass screens set in fixed steel frames are deemed to be in compliance, or a 20 min fire-protection rating, existing 45 mm solid core wood doors equipped with self-closing devices and existing solid wood frames are deemed to be in compliance.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Existing doors to bedrooms not conforming to Sentences (1) to (3) may be approved.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Despite Sentence (1), and except as permitted in Article 9.4.2.9., door assemblies required to have a 20 min fire-protection rating shall be equipped with self-closing devices.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Despite Sentences (1) and (2), fire dampers or fire-stop flaps are not required in ducts at penetrations of an existing fire separation.
Where a door to a bedroom is not equipped with a self-closing device, a latch that can hold the door in the closed position shall be installed.
Fuel-fired appliances shall be enclosed in a service room separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.
Sentence (1) does not apply to a fuel-fired appliance that serves only one bedroom.

Despite Sentence (1), if the required vertical fire separation to a service room is provided and it is not practical in the circumstances to install a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min above the service room, the service room area shall be sprinklered with a spacing not exceeding 9.5 m2 per sprinkler head.

Where a furnace room is separated to comply with the requirements of Article 9.4.2.10., sufficient combustion air shall be brought directly from the exterior for the proper combustion and safe operation of the appliance.
A transformer vault shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 2 h.
Vertical service spaces shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.

Where openings in the vertical service space, including the top and bottom, are sealed with noncombustible materials having the same fire-resistance rating as the existing construction, the vertical service space is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).
Automatic sprinklers shall be installed at the top and at alternate floor levels in each linen or refuse chute and in the room or bin into which the chute discharges.

An existing linen chute installation is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where the room into which the linen chute discharges is sprinklered and at least one sprinkler head is installed at the top of the linen chute.
Each room into which a linen or refuse chute discharges shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h.
Incinerators shall be enclosed in a service room separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 2 h.

Bedrooms or compartments containing related rooms on a floor area shall have a doorway leading to an interior corridor where it shall be possible to go in opposite directions to each of two separate exits.

Access to exits through a dead end corridor is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where the number of persons served does not exceed 10 persons, and the travel distance does not exceed 6 m plus the width of the dead end corridor, to a point where a choice of two directions of exit travel is available.

Where a bedroom or a compartment containing related rooms is served by an exit door leading directly to the outside or to an exterior passageway, a doorway leading to an interior corridor served by one exit is deemed to be in compliance with Sentences (1) and (2).

Where a dead end corridor does not satisfy the travel distance as described in Sentence (2), the existing corridor is deemed to be in compliance where additional fire protection measures are provided that are approved.
Each floor area used by patients or residents shall be served by not fewer than two exits.
Each exit stairway shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.
Closures in stairway fire separations shall conform to Article 9.4.2.8.
Each exit door shall open in the direction of exit travel and swing on its vertical axis.
Existing door swing arrangements not in conformance with Sentence (1) may be approved.
Signs for exits and access to exits shall comply with the requirements of Article 3.4.5.1. of the 1986 Building Code.
Despite Sentence (1), existing signs may be approved.

A fire escape shall not be erected on an existing building unless it is not practical in the circumstances to provide one or more exit facilities, described under Article 3.4.1.2. of the 1986 Building Code, and provided that the fire escape does not serve floor areas above the second floor.

A fire escape permitted under Sentence (1) shall be constructed to comply with the requirements of Article 3.4.7.13. of the 1986 Building Code, except that the fire escape shall not be less than 1100 mm in width when serving floor areas with non-ambulatory residents.
Despite Sentences (1) and (2), an existing fire escape may be approved.
Emergency lighting shall be provided in accordance with the provisions of Article 3.2.7.3. of the 1986 Building Code.
A fire alarm and detection system shall be installed in each building.
Fire alarm and detection systems shall comply with the requirements of Subsection 3.2.4. of the 1986 Building Code.

Despite Sentence (1), in buildings constructed prior to December 1, 1983, heat detectors may be installed in bedrooms, corridors and stair shafts to satisfy the 1986 Building Code, except where other detection is required by Sentences 9.4.2.3.(3), 9.4.2.5.(2) or 9.4.2.6.(4).

Despite Sentences (1) and (2), where the Chief Fire Official is satisfied that the performance and reliability of an existing fire alarm system will provide an adequate early warning level, the existing system may remain, be modified or be extended, provided compatibility of components is maintained.

Each fire alarm system shall be connected to the fire department headquarters by a direct connection, provided the fire department has the necessary facilities to accept such a connection, or a central station or proprietary control station.
Where the provisions required in Sentence (1) are not available, a procedure for notifying the fire department shall be approved.
Recirculating air handling systems that serve more than 1 storey or more than one zone as described in Sentence 9.4.2.7.(1) shall be arranged to shut down upon actuation of the fire alarm system.

In buildings greater than 6 storeys in building height, air handling systems serving more than 1 storey or more than one zone as described in Article 9.4.2.7. shall be arranged to shut down upon actuation of the fire alarm system, except where continued operation of the air handling system serves as part of a smoke control system.
Access routes for fire fighting shall be provided in accordance with the requirements of Article 3.2.5.2. of the 1986 Building Code.
Sentence (1) does not apply where the building is sprinklered.

Access routes that do not comply with Sentence (1) may be approved where available fire department equipment has access to the building or alternative provisions are made under Subsection 2.8.2. for such access.
Sprinkler systems shall be designed in conformance with Article 3.2.5.5. of the 1986 Building Code.

Despite Sentence (1), water supply requirements for sprinkler systems required in this Section may be based on the operation of at least three sprinkler heads spaced not to exceed 14.4 m2 per head, and a sprinkler discharge rate of not less than 100 L/min at any single operating sprinkler head for a duration of 30 min.
Despite Sentences (1) and (2), existing sprinkler systems providing adequate protection may be approved.
In buildings greater than 6 storeys in building height, at least one elevator shall be provided for use by firefighters.

An elevator is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where the elevator is capable of providing transportation from the street floor to each floor normally served by the elevator system, the elevator is identified on the street floor as an elevator for use by firefighters, the elevator satisfies the requirements of Article 3.2.6.3. of the 1986 Building Code, and other elevator cabs in the same shaft as the elevator for use by firefighters satisfy the requirements of Sentences 3.2.6.3.(1) and (2) of the 1986 Building Code.
In buildings greater than 6 storeys in building height, a voice communication system shall be provided in accordance with the requirements of Article 3.2.4.16. of the 1986 Building Code.
A public address system compatible with the fire safety plan required under Subsection 2.8.2. is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).
Buildings containing a home described in Clause 9.4.1.1.(1)(a) or (b) that is a care occupancy or a care and treatment occupancy shall be sprinklered in conformance with Sentences (2) to (5).
Except as permitted in Sentence (3), an automatic sprinkler system shall be installed in accordance with NFPA 13, "Standard for the Installation of Sprinkler Systems".

In buildings not greater than 6 storeys in building height, sprinkler systems may be installed in accordance with NFPA 13R, "Standard for the Installation of Sprinkler Systems in Residential Occupancies up to and Including Four Stories in Height".
Sprinkler systems shall be equipped with local electric waterflow alarms.

If a fire pump is required by NFPA 13 or NFPA 13R, it shall be installed in accordance with NFPA 20, "Installation of Stationary Pumps for Fire Protection", if it has a rated net head pressure greater than 280 kPa.
Buildings described in Sentence (1) that are sprinklered in conformance with Article 9.4.5.2. on January 1, 2014 are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).

This Section applies to buildings up to and including 6 storeys in building height with residential occupancies and containing
 (a) more than two dwelling units where
 (i) at least two dwelling units share common exit facilities and have interior access to one another,
 (ii) there is at least one dwelling unit located above another with interior access to one another, or
 (iii) there is at least one dwelling unit located above another and the dwelling units share common exit facilities,
 (b) sleeping accommodation for more than 10 persons, in one or more dormitories,
 (c) boarding, lodging or rooming accommodation for more than four persons where Sections 9.3 and 9.4. do not apply, or
 (d) one or two dwelling units in combination with boarding, lodging or rooming accommodation for two, three or four persons, excluding the operator’s residence.

Despite Sentence (1), if a building that is governed by this Section contains, in addition to its residential occupancies, one or more other occupancies that are not governed by any other Section of this Part, this Section does not apply to the fire safety systems, devices and structural elements of the other occupancies that do not affect the life safety of the residential occupancy.

If a building that is governed by this Section contains, in addition to its residential occupancies, one or more other occupancies that are governed by other Sections of this Part, the fire safety systems, devices and structural elements of the other occupancies governed by those Sections shall comply with the requirements of this Part that provide the greatest protection for life safety.
Revoked: O. Reg. 256/14, s. 354 (2).

P/T Article Title: Exemption for convents, monasteries and hotels
P/T Sentence Text: This Section does not apply to convents and monasteries.

P/T Article Title: Exemption for convents, monasteries and hotels
P/T Sentence Text: This Section does not apply to a building or part of a building regulated under Section 9.9.
For the purposes of this Section,
Fire separations required under this Section to have a fire-resistance rating shall comply with Subsection 3.1.7. and Articles 3.1.8.1., 3.1.8.2., 3.1.8.3. and 3.5.4.2. of the 1990 Building Code.

If a fire-resistance rating of 1 h or less is required, existing wall assemblies, floor assemblies, ceilings and their supporting assemblies, consisting of membranes of lath and plaster or gypsum board, are deemed to comply with Sentence (1).
Heavy timber construction that complies with Article 3.1.4.6. of the 1990 Building Code is deemed to have a 45 min fire-resistance rating.
Buildings with limited combustible components may be approved as noncombustible construction.
Floor assemblies shall be constructed as fire separations with fire-resistance ratings that comply with Articles 9.5.2.2. to 9.5.2.5.
Sentence (5) does not apply to floor assemblies between different levels of the same multi-level dwelling unit.

Buildings shall comply with the requirements of Sentence (2) where the building is not more than 1 storey in building height and not greater than 1200 m2 in building area, not more than 2 storeys in building height and not greater than 900 m2 in building area, or not more than 3 storeys in building height and not greater than 600 m2 in building area.
Floor assemblies and walls, columns and arches supporting floor assemblies shall have a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min.

Where sleeping accommodation, recreation rooms, meeting rooms or hobby rooms are not provided in the basement, an existing fire separation between the first storey and basement is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (2) where
 (a) the basement is sprinklered, or
 (b) the building contains not more than four dwelling units and provides sleeping accommodation for not more than 10 persons, and
 (i) interconnected smoke alarms are installed in accordance with Article 9.5.4.4.,
 (ii) doors connecting the basement and first storey are in compliance with Sentence 9.5.2.8.(4), and
 (iii) fire stopping of the wall space at the basement level is in accordance with Article 9.10.15.3. of the 1990 Building Code.

The water supply for the sprinklers referred to in Clause (3)(a) may be taken from the domestic supply where the supply provides sufficient density for the largest fire compartment and where the supply is approved.
Buildings are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence 9.5.2.2.(2) where the building is sprinklered, or the building is 1 storey in building height and is not greater than 600 m2 in building area.
Buildings to which Sentence 9.5.2.2.(1) does not apply and which are not more than 4 storeys in building height shall comply with Sentences (2) and (3).
Floor assemblies and walls, columns and arches supporting floor assemblies shall have a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.
Smoke detectors shall be provided as fire detectors in public corridors serving dwelling units in buildings of combustible construction.
A building that is sprinklered is deemed to be in compliance with Sentences (2) and (3).

Buildings that are more than 4 storeys in building height shall have a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min for floor assemblies and walls, columns and arches supporting floor assemblies, and be sprinklered, where the building is of combustible construction.

Where only the roof assembly is of combustible construction, the building is deemed to be in compliance with Clause (1)(b) where ceiling membrane has a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min and the attic space is fire stopped in accordance with Article 3.1.11.5. of the 1990 Building Code, the roof assembly is of heavy timber construction in accordance with Article 3.1.4.6. of the 1990 Building Code, or the top storey and attic space are sprinklered.

Where smoke detectors are provided in public corridors, a building of heavy timber construction conforming to Article 3.1.4.6. of the 1990 Building Code is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).
Fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h shall be provided between residential occupancies and other major occupancies.

Existing fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min are deemed to comply with Sentence (1) if the building is sprinklered and the sprinkler system complies with Article 9.5.5.3., or the part of the building containing the other major occupancy is equipped with heat detectors and connecting corridors are equipped with smoke detectors as part of the fire alarm system of the building.
Existing fire separations consisting of membranes of lath and plaster or gypsum board are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).

P/T Article Title: Fire separations between dwelling units and corridors
P/T Sentence Text: Each dwelling unit and sleeping room not within a dwelling unit shall be separated from adjacent rooms and areas by fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min.

P/T Article Title: Fire separations between dwelling units and corridors
P/T Sentence Text: Public corridors shall be separated from adjacent rooms and areas by fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min.

P/T Article Title: Fire separations between dwelling units and corridors
P/T Sentence Text: If the floor area is sprinklered, existing fire separations are deemed to comply with Sentences (1) and (2).

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Closures in fire separations shall be in accordance with Sentences 3.1.8.4.(2), 3.1.8.10.(1) and 3.1.8.11.(1) and Article 3.1.8.13. of the 1990 Building Code.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Openings in a fire separation that is required to have a 30 min fire-resistance rating shall be protected with closures having a 20 min fire-protection rating.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: If a 45 min fire-protection rating is required, existing closures are deemed to comply with Sentence (1) if they consist of hollow metal or kalamein doors in hollow metal frames, with openings, if any, protected by wired glass, and equipped with self-closing devices, or wired glass screens set in fixed steel frames.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Where a 20 min fire-protection rating is required, existing closures consisting of 45 mm solid core wood doors installed in solid wood or hollow metal frames and equipped with self-closing devices are deemed to be in compliance with Sentences (1) and (2).

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Existing closures in fire separations to which Article 9.5.2.7. applies are deemed to be in compliance with Sentences (1) and (2) where the floor area is sprinklered, or interconnected smoke alarms are installed in accordance with Article 9.5.4.4., the building has not more than four dwelling units and the building provides sleeping accommodation for not more than 10 persons.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Despite Sentence (1), closures in fire separations to which Article 9.5.2.7. applies do not require self-closing devices, except as required in Sentences 9.5.3.1.(2) and 9.5.3.3.(3).

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Existing operable transoms and glass lights shall be fixed shut and shall meet the fire-protection rating requirements of Sentences (1) and (2).

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Despite Sentences (1) and (2), fire dampers or fire-stop flaps are not required in existing noncombustible ducts at penetrations of fire separations.

Storage rooms for the use of occupants, not contained within a dwelling unit or suite,
 (a) shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min, and
 (b) shall be
 (i) sprinklered, or
 (ii) subdivided into areas not exceeding 150 m2 by fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min and equipped with fire detectors connected to the fire alarm system.

Existing storage rooms are deemed to be in compliance with Clause (1)(b) where the building contains not more than four dwelling units and provides sleeping accommodation for not more than 10 persons.

Existing storage rooms are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where the building contains not more than four dwelling units and provides sleeping accommodation for not more than 10 persons, and sleeping rooms are not located on the same floor as storage rooms.

Fuel-fired appliances shall be enclosed in a service room separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min if the building height is greater than 2 storeys or the building area is greater than 400 m2. the building contains not more than four dwelling units and provides sleeping accommodation for not more than 10 persons, and sleeping rooms are not located on the same floor as storage rooms.
Sentence (1) does not apply to a fuel-fired appliance that serves only one dwelling unit or suite.

Despite Sentence (1), the fire-resistance rating of the fire separation above the service room is not required where the required vertical fire separation to a service room is provided, and the service room area is sprinklered, with a spacing not exceeding 9.5 m2 per sprinkler head, or providing a minimum average density of 6.5 L/min/m2 over the room area.

Where a service room is separated in accordance with Article 9.5.2.10., sufficient combustion air shall be brought directly from the outside for the proper combustion and safe operation of the appliances.
Incinerator rooms and refuse storage rooms shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.
Refuse storage rooms shall be sprinklered with a spacing that does not exceed 9.5 m2 per sprinkler head or that provides a minimum average density of 6.5 L/min/m2 over the room area.

Vertical service spaces shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating equivalent to that required for the floor assemblies within the building in accordance with Articles 9.5.2.2. to 9.5.2.5.

Where openings in the vertical service space, including the top and bottom, are sealed with noncombustible materials having the same fire-resistance rating as the existing construction, the vertical service space is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).
Each room into which a linen or refuse chute discharges shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h.
Automatic sprinklers shall be installed in each linen or refuse chute at the top, at alternate floor levels, and in the room or bin into which the chute discharges.

Where the room into which the linen or refuse chute discharges is sprinklered and at least one sprinkler head is installed at the top of the chute, an existing chute installation is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (2).
Despite Sentence 9.5.2.1.(1), a closure is not required at the opening between a linen or refuse chute and the room into which it discharges.
A storage garage shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.

Each dwelling unit or suite in a floor area shall have a doorway leading to the outside at or near grade, an outside passageway where it is possible to go in opposite directions to separate exits, or a public corridor where it is possible to go in opposite directions to separate exits.

Access to exits through a dead end public corridor is deemed to be in compliance with Clause (1)(c) where  the distance along the dead end does not exceed 6 m plus the width of the corridor, measured from any door along the corridor to a point where a choice of two directions of exit travel is available, and self-closing devices are provided on suite entrance doors opening onto the dead end portion of the corridor.

Access to exits through a dead end corridor in boarding, lodging or rooming accommodation is deemed to be in compliance with Clause (1)(c) where the building is not more than 3 storeys in building height, sleeping accommodation is provided for not more than 10 persons, not more than two persons require assistance to evacuate the building in a fire emergency, smoke alarms are installed in the means of egress in accordance with Sentence 9.5.4.1.(2), and the building complies with the requirements of Section 2.8.

Existing dead end public corridors are deemed to be in compliance with Clause (2)(a) where additional fire protection measures are approved that, in the opinion of the Chief Fire Official, will provide protection for life safety similar to the protection provided by compliance with Clause (2)(a). uirements of Section 2.8.

Despite Sentence (1), if a dwelling unit or suite has access to a second and separate exit or the building complies with Sentence 9.5.3.2.(2) or (3), a doorway from the dwelling unit or suite may open onto an exit stairway, a fire escape, a public corridor served by a single exit, or an outside passageway served by a single exit stairway.
Each floor area shall be served by a minimum of two exits.

A single exit from a basement, first or second floor is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where the exit does not serve more than four dwelling units, the exit does not serve more than 10 persons and the building is not more than 3 storeys in building height and is not greater than 600 m2 in building area.

Where a building is not more than 3 storeys in building height and not greater than 600 m2 in building area, alternative measures to Sentence (1) may be used if they are approved, and in the opinion of the Chief Fire Official, will provide protection for life safety similar to the protection provided by compliance with Sentence (1).
Each exit stairway shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.
If the building is 3 storeys or less in building height, a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min is deemed to comply with Sentence (1).
Closures in stairway fire separations referred to in Sentences (1) and (2) shall be equipped with self-closing devices.

Where the occupant load in a building exceeds 24 persons or there are more than 10 dwelling units, each exit door, except those serving a single dwelling unit, shall open in the direction of exit travel and swing on its vertical axis.

Each exit door, except for the main entrance to a building, dwelling unit or suite, shall have an exit sign when the exit serves a building exceeding 2 storeys in building height, a building having an occupant load greater than 150 persons, or a floor area other than a single dwelling unit with a fire escape as part of a means of egress.
Where exit signs are not visible throughout the corridors and passageways, additional exit signs shall be installed in approved locations to indicate the direction of egress.

Exit signs required in Sentences (1) and (2) shall have the word "EXIT" or the words "EXIT/SORTIE" in red letters on a contrasting background or white letters on a red background, letters with strokes at least 19 mm wide, letters at least 150 mm high when the signs are externally illuminated, and letters at least 114 mm high when the signs are internally illuminated.
Flame-spread ratings of interior wall and ceiling finishes within a means of egress shall not exceed 150.

Despite Sentence (1), existing interior wall and ceiling finishes within an access to exit may be approved if, in the opinion of the Chief Fire Official, they will provide protection for life safety similar to the protection provided by compliance with Sentence (1).
Each fire escape used as an exit shall comply with Articles 3.4.7.2., 3.4.7.3., 3.4.7.5. and 3.4.7.6. of the 1990 Building Code.

If a fire escape serves any storey above the second floor, doorway openings and window openings shall be protected in accordance with Sentences (3) and (4) if located within 3 m horizontally of any balcony, platform or stairway of the fire escape, within 3 storeys below or 10 m below any balcony, platform or stairway of the fire escape, or within 1.8 m above any balcony, platform or stairway of the fire escape.

Doorway openings referred to in Sentence (2) shall be protected with closures having a fire-protection rating not less than 20 min and equipped with self-closing devices. within 3 m horizontally of any balcony, platform or stairway of the fire escape, within 3 storeys below or 10 m below any balcony, platform or stairway of the fire escape, or within 1.8 m above any balcony, platform or stairway of the fire escape.

Window openings referred to in Sentence (2) shall be protected with closures having a fire-protection rating not less than 20 min and that are fixed shut or arranged to close automatically upon the operation of a fusible link, wired glass screens set in fixed steel frames, glass block, or listed steel shutters arranged to close automatically upon the operation of a fusible link.
The fusible link referred to in Clauses (4)(a) and (d) shall comply with ULC-S505, "Standard for Fusible Links for Fire Protection Service".
The wired glass screens and glass block referred to in Clauses (4)(b) and (c) shall be installed in accordance with Article 3.1.8.14. of the 1990 Building Code.
Public corridors and stairways that form part of a means of egress shall be adequately illuminated to allow for the safe evacuation of occupants.

Emergency lighting shall be provided in exit stairways, public corridors and other principal access to exits where the occupant load in a building exceeds 24 persons or there are more than 10 dwelling units.

Emergency lighting required in Sentence (1) shall be designed to provide illumination for a duration of at least 30 min, supplied by a source of energy separate from the primary electrical supply for the building, and designed to be automatically actuated when the power to the building is interrupted.
Illumination from emergency lighting shall be an average of at least 10 lx at floor or tread level, or 1 watt/m2 of floor space.

A fire alarm system shall be installed in accordance with Articles 3.2.4.2. to 3.2.4.6., 3.2.4.8., 3.2.4.9. and 3.2.4.17. and Sentences 3.2.7.8.(1) to (4) of the 1990 Building Code, where the building is greater than 3 storeys in building height, or sleeping accommodation is provided for more than 10 persons.

A building not greater than 3 storeys in building height that contains not more than 10 dwelling units and provides sleeping accommodation for not more than 24 persons is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where the building is equipped with smoke alarms in accordance with Article 9.5.4.4., installed and interconnected so that the actuation of any smoke alarm will sound a similar signal in each of the interconnected devices, and a manual pull station at each exterior exit door for the actuation of the smoke alarms in Clause (a).

A building is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where each exit and public corridor is shared by not more than four dwelling units or not more than 10 persons in boarding, lodging, rooming or dormitory accommodation, or each dwelling unit and suite has direct access to outdoors by a door near ground level.

Existing manually operated, non-electric alarm systems employing mechanical gongs are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence 9.5.4.1.(1), where the building is not more than 2 storeys in building height, not more than two manual fire alarm stations are required in the building, and each gong is audible in every location in the building.
Automatic detection devices referred to in Sentences (2) and (3) shall be installed and connected to the fire alarm system required in Sentence 9.5.4.1.(1).

Fire detectors shall be installed in storage rooms, locker rooms, service rooms, machinery rooms, heating rooms, incinerator rooms, linen and refuse chute intake compartments, janitors" closets and refuse storage rooms, at the tops of elevator shafts and exit stair shafts and in any room or area where hazardous or combustible materials may be used or stored.
Rooms or areas that are sprinklered in accordance with Article 3.2.4.16. of the 1990 Building Code are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (2).

Interconnected smoke alarms required in Sentence 9.5.4.1.(2), Subclause 9.5.2.2.(3)(b)(i) or Clause 9.5.2.8.(5)(b) shall be installed on or near the ceiling in public corridors of each floor area, adjacent to each stairway serving the public corridor and on or near the ceiling in the basement, adjacent to each stairway, audible throughout the suites, connected to an electrical circuit with no disconnect switch between the overcurrent device and the smoke alarms, and listed for use in an interconnected installation.
Smoke alarms shall be installed in each dwelling unit and in each sleeping room not within a dwelling unit in accordance with Article 3.2.4.21. of the 1990 Building Code.
Battery-operated smoke alarms are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence 3.2.4.21.(4) of the 1990 Building Code.
Smoke alarms shall meet the requirements of CAN/ULC-S531, "Standard for Smoke Alarms", and CAN/ULC-S553, "Standard for the Installation of Smoke-Alarms".
Revoked: O. Reg. 256/14, s. 372 (2).

Despite Articles 9.5.4.1. to 9.5.4.4., where the performance and reliability of an existing fire alarm system will provide an adequate early warning level, the existing system may remain, be modified or be extended, if compatibility of the components is maintained and the system is approved.
Access routes for fire fighting shall be provided in accordance with the requirements of Articles 3.2.5.5. to 3.2.5.7. of the 1990 Building Code.
Sentence (1) does not apply where the building is sprinklered.

A standpipe and hose system in accordance with Articles 3.2.9.1. to 3.2.9.7. of the 1990 Building Code shall be installed in buildings more than 4 storeys in building height where the fifth or sixth storey is used for a residential occupancy.

A wet or dry standpipe system is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where it includes a 50 mm riser and 50 mm extensions, capped 38 mm hose valves located so that any point on the floor area may be reached by 30 m of hose plus 3 m of hose stream from at least one hose valve, a fire department connection in accordance with Sentences 3.2.9.5.(2) to (9) of the 1990 Building Code, and a water supply in accordance with Sentences 3.2.9.3.(1) to (3) of the 1990 Building Code.

Despite Sentences (1) and (2), existing standpipe systems and water supplies may be used if the systems or measures will provide sufficient fire suppression capability in the circumstances and if the systems or measures are approved.
Where a building or portion thereof is required to be sprinklered, the sprinkler system shall be designed and constructed in accordance with Articles 3.2.5.13. to 3.2.5.16. of the 1990 Building Code.

Existing sprinkler systems are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) if the average sprinkler discharge density over the design area is at least equal to the minimum density corresponding to the area for light hazard classification as defined in NFPA 13, "Standard for the Installation of Sprinkler Systems", or NFPA 13R, "Standard for the Installation of Sprinkler Systems in Residential Occupancies up to and Including Four Stories in Height", whichever is applicable.
Despite Sentences (1) and (2), existing sprinkler systems providing adequate protection that will control or extinguish fire and that are approved may be used.

This Section applies to buildings higher than 6 storeys in building height with residential occupancies and containing more than two dwelling units, sleeping accommodation for more than 10 persons in one or more dormitories, or boarding, lodging or rooming accommodation for more than 10 persons.

Despite Sentence (1), if a building containing a residential occupancy that is governed by this Section contains, in addition to its residential occupancies, one or more other occupancies that are not governed by this Part, this Section does not apply to the fire safety systems, devices or structural elements of any of the other occupancies that do not affect the life safety of the residential occupancy.

If a building that is governed by this Section contains, in addition to its residential occupancies, one or more other occupancies that are governed by other Sections of this Part, the fire safety systems, devices and structural elements of all of the occupancies governed by this Part shall comply with the requirements of this Part that provide the greatest protection for life safety.
Revoked: O. Reg. 256/14, s. 375.

P/T Article Title: Exemption for convents, monasteries and hotels
P/T Sentence Text: This Section does not apply to convents and monasteries.

P/T Article Title: Exemption for convents, monasteries and hotels
P/T Sentence Text: This Section does not apply to a building or part of a building regulated under Section 9.9.
For the purposes of this Section,
Fire separations required under this Section to have a fire-resistance rating shall comply with Subsection 3.1.7. and Articles 3.1.8.1., 3.1.8.3., and 3.5.4.2. of the 1990 Building Code.

If a fire-resistance rating of 1 h or less is required, existing wall assemblies, floor assemblies and their supporting assemblies are deemed to comply with Sentence (1) if they consist of reinforced concrete, masonry, clay tile with plaster or gypsum board finish on both sides, or membranes of lath and plaster or gypsum board.
Floor assemblies shall be fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h.
Walls, columns and arches supporting floor assemblies shall have a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h.
Sentences (1) and (2) do not apply to floor assemblies between different levels of the same multi-level dwelling unit.
Buildings of combustible construction shall be sprinklered.

Where only the roof assembly is of combustible construction, the building is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where the ceiling membrane has a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min and the attic space is fire stopped in accordance with Article 3.1.11.5. of the 1990 Building Code, the roof assembly is of heavy timber construction in accordance with Article 3.1.4.6. of the 1990 Building Code, or the top storey and attic space are sprinklered.
Fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h shall be provided between residential occupancies and other major occupancies.
Existing fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min are deemed to comply with Sentence (1) if the other major occupancy is sprinklered.

P/T Article Title: Fire separations between dwelling units and corridors
P/T Sentence Text: Each dwelling unit and sleeping room not within a dwelling unit shall be separated from adjacent rooms and areas by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.

P/T Article Title: Fire separations between dwelling units and corridors
P/T Sentence Text: Public corridors shall be separated from adjacent rooms and areas by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min.

P/T Article Title: Fire separations between dwelling units and corridors
P/T Sentence Text: Existing fire separations having less than a 45 min fire-resistance rating are deemed to be in compliance with Sentences (1) and (2) where the floor area is sprinklered.

P/T Article Title: Fire separations between dwelling units and corridors
P/T Sentence Text: Existing fire separations having a fire-resistance rating not less than 30 min are deemed to comply with Sentences (1) and (2) if smoke detectors are installed in public corridors.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Closures in fire separations shall be in accordance with Sentences 3.1.8.4.(2), 3.1.8.10.(1) and 3.1.8.11.(1) and Articles 3.1.8.13. and 3.3.4.5. of the 1990 Building Code.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Openings in fire separations required to have a 30 min fire-resistance rating shall be protected with closures having a 20 min fire-protection rating.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Where a 1.5 h fire-protection rating is required, existing closures consisting of hollow metal or kalamein doors in hollow metal frames, with openings, if any, protected by wired glass panels not exceeding 645 cm2, and equipped with self-closing and latching devices are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Where a 1 h or 45 min fire-protection rating is required, existing closures are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where they consist of hollow metal or kalamein doors in hollow metal frames, with openings, if any, protected by wired glass, and equipped with self-closing and latching devices, or wired glass screens set in fixed steel frames.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Where a 20 min fire-protection rating is required, or in a fire separation required under Article 9.6.2.5., existing closures consisting of 45 mm solid core wood doors installed in solid wood or hollow metal frames and equipped with self-closing and latching devices are deemed to be in compliance with Sentences (1) and (2).

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Where the floor area is sprinklered, existing closures in fire separations to which Article 9.6.2.5. applies are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (2) and Sentences 3.1.8.4.(2) and 3.1.8.10.(1) of the 1990 Building Code.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Despite Sentence (1), garbage intake room doors that swing inward shall be acceptable without a latching device.

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Existing operable transoms and glass lights shall be fixed shut and shall meet the fire-protection rating requirements of Sentences (1) and (2).

P/T Article Title: Protection of openings in fire separations
P/T Sentence Text: Despite Sentences (1) and (2), fire dampers or fire-stop flaps are not required in existing noncombustible ducts at penetrations of fire separations.

Storage rooms for the use of occupants, not contained within a dwelling unit or suite, shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h, and sprinklered in accordance with Article 9.6.5.5.

Despite Clause (1)(b), existing sprinkler systems or alternate fire protection systems that will control or extinguish fire and that are approved may be used. separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h, and sprinklered in accordance with Article 9.6.5.5.
Fuel-fired appliances shall be enclosed in a service room separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h.
Sentence (1) does not apply to fuel-fired appliances that serve only one dwelling unit or suite.
Incinerator rooms shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 2 h.
A fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h is deemed to comply with Sentence (1) if the incinerator room is sprinklered.

Where a service room is separated in accordance with Article 9.6.2.8., sufficient combustion air shall be brought directly from the outside for the proper combustion and safe operation of the appliances.

Refuse storage rooms shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h, and sprinklered to provide a minimum average density of 6.5 L/m2 over the room area.

Vertical service spaces shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 45 min. separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h, and sprinklered to provide a minimum average density of 6.5 L/m2 over the room area.

Where openings in the vertical service space, including the top and bottom, are sealed with noncombustible materials having the same fire-resistance rating as the existing construction, the vertical service space is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).
Each room into which a linen or refuse chute discharges shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1 h.
Automatic sprinklers shall be installed in each linen or refuse chute at the top, at alternate floor levels, and in the room or bin into which the chute discharges.

An existing chute installation is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (2) where the chute outlet in the discharge room is protected by an automatic, self-latching closure held open by a fusible link, the room into which the chute discharges is sprinklered, and at least one sprinkler head with a minimum discharge rate of 66 L/min is located at the top of the chute.

Transformer vaults to which the Electricity Act, 1998 applies shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 2 h and shall be provided with heat detectors connected to the fire alarm system.
A storage garage shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1.5 h.
Underground storage garages shall be sprinklered.

Sentence (2) does not apply to an underground storage garage that is equipped with heat detectors connected to the fire alarm system and that has vestibules located at points of access to the residential occupancy.
Buildings where the vertical distance between the floor of the top storey and grade exceeds 18 m shall have smoke control measures in accordance with Article 3.2.6.2. of the 1990 Building Code.

Buildings are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where all dwelling units have access to an exterior balcony, the length of public corridors does not exceed 30 m between exits, public corridors on each floor area are equipped with smoke detectors connected to the fire alarm system, public corridors on each floor area are subdivided in accordance with Sentence (3), or the building is fully sprinklered.

The public corridor subdivision referred to in Clause (2)(d) shall\n separate the corridor into at least two compartments by a fire separation, be located so that no more than one of the required exit stairs is located in any one compartment and the distance of travel from any suite entrance door to an exit or adjacent compartment does not exceed 25 m, and include smoke-tight doors equipped with self-closing devices that act as closures in the fire separation.

Each dwelling unit or suite in a floor area shall have a doorway leading to the outside at or near grade, an outside passageway where it is possible to go in opposite directions to separate exits, or a public corridor where it is possible to go in opposite directions to separate exits.

Access to exits through a dead end public corridor is deemed to be in compliance with Clause (1)(c) where the distance of travel, measured from any door along the corridor to a point where a choice of two directions of exit travel is available, does not exceed 6 m plus the width of the corridor.

Existing dead end public corridors are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (2) where additional fire protection measures are approved that, in the opinion of the Chief Fire Official, will provide protection for life safety similar to the protection provided by compliance with Sentence (2).

Despite Sentence (1), if a dwelling unit or suite has access to a second and separate exit, a doorway from the dwelling unit or suite may open onto an exit stairway, a public corridor served by a single exit, or an outside passageway served by a single exit stairway.
Each floor area shall be served by a minimum of two exits.
The minimum distance between exits shall be 9 m or half the maximum diagonal dimension of the floor area, whichever is less.
The travel distance to at least one exit shall not exceed 30 m in a floor area that is not sprinklered, or 45 m in a sprinklered floor area.
Each exit stairway shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire separation having a fire-resistance rating not less than 1h.
Closures in stairway fire separations shall be in accordance with Article 9.6.2.6.
Each exit door, except those serving a single dwelling unit, shall open in the direction of exit travel and swing on its vertical axis.
Exit signs shall be installed in accordance with Subsection 3.4.5. of the 1990 Building Code.

Each door opening into an exit stairway from a public corridor shall be identified on the stairway side with the number assigned to that floor in accordance with Article 3.4.6.17. of the 1990 Building Code.
Flame-spread ratings of interior wall and ceiling finishes within a means of egress shall be in accordance with Article 3.1.13.7. of the 1990 Building Code.

Despite Sentence (1), existing interior wall and ceiling finishes within an access to exit may be approved if, in the opinion of the Chief Fire Official, they will provide protection for life safety similar to the protection provided by compliance with Sentence (1).
Public corridors and stairways that form part of a means of egress shall be adequately illuminated to allow for the safe evacuation of occupants.
Emergency lighting shall be provided in exit stairways, public corridors and other principal access to exits.

Emergency lighting required in Sentence (1) shall be
 (a) designed to provide illumination for a duration of at least 
 (i) 2 h in buildings whose highest floor level is more than 18 m above grade, and
 (ii) 30 min in buildings whose highest floor level is not more than 18 m above grade,
 (b) supplied by a source of energy separate from the primary electrical supply for the building, and
 (c) designed to be automatically actuated when the power to the building is interrupted.

Illumination from emergency lighting shall be an average of at least 10 lx at floor or tread level, or 1 watt/m2 of floor space. designed to provide illumination for a duration of at least 2 h in buildings whose highest floor level is more than 18 m above grade, and 30 min in buildings whose highest floor level is not more than 18 m above grade, supplied by a source of energy separate from the primary electrical supply for the building, and 2 h in buildings whose highest floor level is more than 18 m above grade, and 30 min in buildings whose highest floor level is not more than 18 m above grade, designed to be automatically actuated when the power to the building is interrupted.
A fire alarm and detection system shall be installed in each building in accordance with Articles 3.2.4.1. to 3.2.4.14., 3.2.4.16. to 3.2.4.20., 3.2.4.22. and 3.2.7.8. of the 1990 Building Code.

An existing fire alarm system is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where the system complies with Articles 9.6.4.2. to 9.6.4.9., and operates in accordance with Article 3.2.4.4. of the 1990 Building Code.
Automatic detection devices referred to in Sentences (2) and (3) shall be installed and connected to the fire alarm system required in Sentence 9.6.4.1.(2).

Fire detectors shall be installed in storage rooms, locker rooms, service rooms, machinery rooms, heating rooms, incinerator rooms, linen and refuse chute intake compartments, janitors" closets and refuse storage rooms, at the tops of elevator shafts and exit stair shafts and in any room or area where hazardous or combustible materials may be used or stored.
Rooms or areas that are sprinklered in accordance with Article 3.2.4.16. of the 1990 Building Code are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (2).
Manual pull stations shall be provided in accordance with Article 3.2.4.17. of the 1990 Building Code.
The fire alarm system shall be electrically supervised.
Despite Sentence (1), electrical supervision of the bell circuits is not required where bells operate on more than one circuit on each floor.

An annunciator panel shall be located at the main street entrance to the building or a location that is accessible to the fire department and that is approved, and indicate all floors with not more than one floor per zone indicated.
Despite Clause (1)(b), existing annunciator zone indication that is compatible with the fire safety plan required under Subsection 2.8.2. and that is approved may be used.

Fire alarm systems in buildings where the vertical distance between the floor of the top storey and grade exceeds 18 m shall have provision for notifying the fire department in accordance with Sentences 3.2.4.7.(1) to (4) of the 1990 Building Code that a fire alarm signal or alert signal has been initiated.
A voice communication system shall be provided where the vertical distance between the floor of the top storey and grade exceeds 36 m.

The voice communication system required by Sentence (1) shall consist of loudspeakers operated from the central alarm and control facility or other location that is accessible to the fire department and supervisory staff required under Subsection 2.8.2. and that is approved, provide a clear verbal signal throughout the building, except for within elevator cars, and provide for automatic silencing of the fire alarm devices when the loudspeakers are in use.

Approved existing public address systems compatible with the fire safety plan required under Subsection 2.8.2. and capable of communicating instructions to the building occupants are deemed to be in compliance with Sentences (1) and (2).
Fire alarm and voice communication systems shall be provided with an electrically supervised emergency power supply in accordance with Article 3.2.7.8. of the 1990 Building Code.

Recirculating air handling systems that serve more than one dwelling unit, suite or storey shall be equipped with a duct-type smoke detector that will automatically shut down the system upon actuation of the smoke detector.
Smoke alarms shall be installed in each dwelling unit and in each sleeping room not within a dwelling unit in accordance with Article 3.2.4.21. of the 1990 Building Code.
Battery-operated smoke alarms are deemed to be in compliance with Sentence 3.2.4.21.(4) of the 1990 Building Code.
Smoke alarms shall meet the requirements of CAN/ULC-S531, "Standard for Smoke Alarms", and CAN/ULC-S553, "Standard for the Installation of Smoke-Alarms".
Revoked: O. Reg. 256/14, s. 393 (2).
Access routes for fire fighting shall be provided in accordance with Articles 3.2.5.5. to 3.2.5.7. of the 1990 Building Code.
Sentence (1) does not apply where the building is sprinklered.
A standpipe and hose system in accordance with Subsection 3.2.9. of the 1990 Building Code shall be installed in each building.

A wet or dry standpipe system is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1) where the system includes a minimum 150 mm diameter riser located in each stairwell, with 38 mm and 65 mm capped fire hose valves at each storey, capped 38 mm fire hose valves located in the public corridor so that any point on a floor area may be reached by 30 m of hose plus 3 m of hose stream from at least one hose valve, flow rates as required by Clauses 3.2.9.3.(4)(b) and (c) of the 1990 Building Code for buildings less than 84 m in height, measured between grade and the ceiling level of the top storey, flow rates as required by Clause 3.2.9.3.(5)(b) of the 1990 Building Code for buildings 84 m or more in height, measured between grade and the ceiling level of the top storey, and a water supply in accordance with Sentences 3.2.9.3.(1) and (2) of the 1990 Building Code.

An existing standpipe and hose system capable of delivering a minimum flow rate of 265 L/min for at least 30 min at a minimum discharge pressure of 345 kPa (gauge) at the two highest and most remote hose valves is deemed to be in compliance with Clauses (2) (a), (c), (d) and (e) if not less than 132 L/min can be supplied from each of the two outlets simultaneously.

Emergency power shall be provided for a standpipe system that is designed with at least one pressure zone located above another, such that the water supply for the booster pump in the upper zone must be supplied from the pump in the zone below.
A fire department connection in accordance with Sentences 3.2.9.5.(2) to (9) of the 1990 Building Code shall be provided.
Despite Sentence (1), a fire department connection is not required where a booster pump equipped with emergency power is provided.
Despite Sentence (1), existing fire department connections that are visible and accessible to the fire department and that are approved may be used.
Hydrants shall be located within 90 m of the building face on which the principal entrance is located.
A hydrant located within 45 m of a fire department connection, as required by Sentence 9.6.5.3.(1), is deemed to be in compliance with Sentence (1).
Despite Sentence (1), existing hydrant locations that provide sufficient fire suppression capability in the circumstances and that are approved may be used.
Where a building or portion thereof is required to be sprinklered, the sprinkler system shall be designed and constructed in accordance with Articles 3.2.5.13. to 3.2.5.16. of the 1990 Building Code.
